StoryTitle: Aiken, South Carolina: Empowering Youth at the Red Shield Youth Center
Excerpt: Through a variety of programs focusing on education, character development, and recreation, the center plays a pivotal role in shaping the future of young individuals in the community.
Body:
Located at 640 Laurens Street NW, the Red Shield Youth Center in Aiken is dedicated to providing a safe and nurturing environment for children and teens. The center offers a range of programs designed to foster personal growth, academic success, and community engagement.

One of the cornerstone initiatives is the Summer Day Camp, which runs from May through July. This program provides youth with opportunities to participate in educational activities, sports, and arts, all aimed at building confidence and skills that will serve them throughout their lives. The camp not only keeps children engaged during the summer months but also instills values of teamwork, discipline, and perseverance.

In addition to the Summer Day Camp, the center offers after-school programs that focus on academic support, mentorship, and character development. These programs are designed to help students succeed academically while also growing into responsible and caring individuals.

The Red Shield Youth Center is more than just a facility—it is a community where young people are encouraged to dream big and are given the tools and support to achieve those dreams. Through the dedication of staff and the generosity of donors, the center continues to make a lasting impact on the lives of Aiken's youth.

Title: Edit Story Entry
StoryTitle: Winston-Salem, North Carolina: A New Chapter for the Red Shield Youth Center
Excerpt: In Winston-Salem, North Carolina, the Red Shield Youth Center has embarked on a new chapter, reaffirming its commitment to providing faith-based, community-focused youth programming.
Body:
The Salvation Army of Greater Winston-Salem has rebranded its youth center to the Ken Carlson Red Shield Youth Center, returning to its original identity and mission. This change reflects a renewed focus on faith-based programming and community engagement, aligning with the core values of The Salvation Army.

Located at 2100 Reynolds Park Road, the center offers a variety of programs aimed at supporting the holistic development of youth. From after-school care and summer camps to mentoring and enrichment activities, the center provides a safe and nurturing environment where children and teens can grow academically, socially, and spiritually.

One of the standout features of the Ken Carlson Red Shield Youth Center is its newly opened Teen Center. This space is designed specifically for older youth, offering a range of activities that promote leadership, creativity, and personal growth. With extended evening and weekend hours, the Teen Center provides a constructive alternative to negative influences, keeping teens engaged and connected to positive role models.

The center's commitment to excellence is evident in its programs and the impact they have on the community. By returning to its roots and embracing its mission, the Ken Carlson Red Shield Youth Center continues to be a place where young people can reach their full potential as productive, caring, and responsible citizens.

Title: Edit Story Entry
StoryTitle: Building Confidence Through Creativity: Aiken Teens Take the Stage
Excerpt: At the Aiken Teen Center, creativity is more than an activity—it’s a gateway to confidence and purpose. Through the new performing arts workshop, teens are discovering that their voices and stories have power.
Body:
This spring, the Aiken Teen Center launched a Performing Arts Workshop designed to help teens explore self-expression through drama, music, and creative storytelling. Over a dozen youth performed in a showcase titled “Voices of Hope”, blending poetry, dance, and song into an evening that celebrated courage and community.

Parents filled the center’s multi-purpose hall, some moved to tears as their children took the stage for the first time. “This isn’t just about performance,” said local coordinator Jasmine Fields. “It’s about giving young people confidence to share their hearts.”

Behind the scenes, volunteers helped coach, set up lighting, and mentor participants in stage presence. “Watching my son find his voice again—it’s something I’ll never forget,” shared one parent. The program will continue this fall, expanding to include scriptwriting and stage design.

Scripture Verse:

“Do not neglect the gift that is in you.” – 1 Timothy 4:14

Volunteer Sign-Up:
Want to help youth discover their gifts? Contact Volunteer Coordinator Michelle Lane at mlane@aikenredshield.org or (803) 555-2094 to join the team.

Title: Edit Story Entry
StoryTitle: How the Red Shield Youth Center Helped One Teen Find His Way
Body:
“If it wasn’t for this place, I would probably be doing things I have no business doing.”

Micah Grier is a teen student who’s been coming to the Red Shield Youth Center on Belmont Avenue every summer since he was five years old. He loves playing basketball in the gym, hanging out in the teen room with his friends and helping around the center when he can. Grier is a respectful young man who understands how valuable his future is, something that wasn’t clear to him when he was younger.

Grier describes his younger self as angry and explosive. He would throw tantrums when he didn’t get his way. Felicia Cohen, the site director for the Red Shield Youth Center on Belmont Avenue, remembers his behavior all too well.

“He would blow up out of nowhere,” said Cohen. “The smallest things just set Micah off.”

Cohen and her staff would often pull Grier out of group activities to let him calm down. It’s a technique Cohen uses frequently with the students.

“Sometimes they get explosive and can’t control their emotions,” said Cohen. “Once they calm down, I give them a few minutes to sit in the office. Then I ask, ‘ok, what happened?’ and then they talk.”

That kind of space was necessary for Grier to express himself, but more importantly, to build his trust with the staff. Over time, Cohen and other camp counselors became mentors for Grier, supporting him both inside and outside the youth center. They attended his football and basketball games, spent time with him during his lunch period and were there for him during difficult life events.

“My first year of middle school, a lot had changed in my environment,” said Grier. “But then I realized that I could talk to people about what was going on and what I was going through.”

One of the people Grier felt he could talk to was Cohen. During their one-on-one time together, there was one piece of advice she gave that stayed with him.

“You can’t let anything control you,” Grier recalls.

Now entering his sophomore year of high school, Grier is a junior staff member and a role model for other children. He helps keep the youth center clean by taking out the trash, sweeping, and mopping the floors. He also assists camp counselors with the younger groups by facilitating games and taking attendance. He takes on additional roles, such as helping with lunch distribution and making copies for activities. Most importantly, he’s having fun and making friends every day.

“When he was younger, I could see him being a leader. He just didn’t know how to show it yet,” said Cohen. “Being in this environment, he had to help others. We told him, ‘Micah, we need you to step up. ’ He has leadership skills, and putting him in a place to be a leader is what I believe helped him.”

Grier is currently on his high school football team and has a 3.2 GPA. He has his eyes set on attending his dream school, Florida State University, when he graduates from high school. He is interested in studying IT and aspires to play in the NFL.

“He’s come a long way, and I’m proud of him,” said Cohen.

Grier feels proud of himself too, saying he no longer lets his emotions control him. He’s focused on school, protecting his mom and sister and searching for a part-time job. Most of all, he’s excited for next summer to create more memories at the Red Shield Youth Center.
